title: Google, Facebook to Require Vaccinations for On-Campus Workers
summary: Google delays planned return to offices until mid-October as U.S. companies take new precautions against Delta variant's spread. Google and Facebook Inc. will require all employees at their U.S. campuses to be vaccinated, joining a number of public and private enterprises taking new precautions as the highly infectious Delta variant of Covid-19 sweeps across the U.S.

title: Activision Employees Demonstrate Over Company's Response to Harassment Suit
summary: CEO Bobby Kotick apologizes before workers' walkout as Call of Duty publisher hires law firm to investigate complaints. Current and former Activision Blizzard Inc. employees participated in virtual and in-person walkouts Wednesday to call for changes to the company's workplace culture amid disappointment with its reaction to allegations made in a recent lawsuit.

title: Time to Roll the Dice on Facebook
summary: Investors buying the social media company may score a longer-term deal. It is time to friend Facebook again.

title: White Evangelicals Resist Covid-19 Vaccine Most Among Religious Groups
summary: Nearly one-quarter don't want shot, new study finds, and church leaders face hurdles persuading them. More than six months into the country's Covid-19 vaccination campaign, evangelical Christians are more resistant to getting the vaccine than other major religious groups, according to newly released data.

title: Ford Posts Surprise Profit Amid Strong New-Car Market
summary: Auto maker expects vehicle production, hit hard by the global chip shortage, to recover in the second half of the year. Ford Motor Co. posted a surprise second-quarter profit and raised its earnings outlook for the year, saying it sees an easing to the computer-chip shortage that has hampered vehicle output for months.

title: The Federal Reserve's Big Inflation Miss
summary: If you bet on the central bank's price forecasts, you lost.. The Federal Reserve employs hundreds of economists whose job is assessing the American economy. So it is remarkable that the Fed is so wrong so often in its economic forecasts. The latest big miss has been its failure to anticipate this year's surge in consumer prices.

title: Two False Narratives About the Capitol Riot
summary: As the Jan. 6 committee meets, politics drowns out the actual story.. The House inquiry on the events of Jan. 6 held its opening hearing Tuesday, and it showed why no Republican should try to brush aside the ugliness of the Capitol riot. The perpetrators who assaulted police that day weren't overenthusiastic tourists, and the mob was not all a "loving crowd," as Donald Trump characterized the audience for his pre-melee speech.

title: The Cost of the School Shutdowns
summary: A new McKinsey study documents the severe student learning loss.. Shutting down schools was among the most destructive policies of the pandemic, and a new report by McKinsey & Co. quantifies the harm.

title: ZZ Top's Dusty Hill Dies at 72
summary: The long-bearded bassist for the Texas blues rock trio died in his sleep. ZZ Top's Dusty Hill, the long-bearded bassist for the million-selling Texas blues rock trio known for such hits as "Legs" and "Gimme All Your Lovin'," has died at age 72.

title: Breaking Bill de Blasio's Windows
summary: The mayor promises to focus on quality-of-life issues. Seriously.. Bill de Blasio has rediscovered "broken windows," the idea that tolerating little disorders such as broken windows in abandoned buildings will eventually lead to larger disorder. This was the gist of the New York mayor's answer Tuesday to a question about the illegal drinking, pot smoking and other behavior that has contributed to the mayhem in Washington Square Park.

title: The Messages in the Marsquakes
summary: Some surprising findings as the InSight lander uses seismology to map out the inside of the Red Planet.. The NASA team operating the InSight lander on Mars last week published its analysis of the more than 700 minor "marsquakes" recorded by the vehicle since it began surface operations on the Red Planet in February 2019. The world now has its first view of the inner workings of another planet, with potential implications for a better understanding of how the solar system developed and the evolution of life on Earth.

title: The American Jobs Plan Is a Call to Arms for the GOP
summary: Republicans have to stop the massive spending bill from transforming the U.S.. There's plenty of action on Capitol Hill, and not all of it has to do with the Jan. 6 Commission. Washington's power and the future of American free enterprise hinge on how the drama surrounding the infrastructure legislation plays out.

title: Student-Athletes Deserve 10-Year Scholarships
summary: Give them the time and resources to finish their degrees after their athletic eligibility runs out.. On June 21, the Supreme Court ruled that the National Collegiate Athletic Association's strict limits on compensation for student-athletes violated antitrust law. The door is now open for college athletes to license their names, images and likenesses.

title: Covid Will Increase Life Expectancy
summary: Last week's bad news reflects a failure to understand statistics.. Life is short, but not as short as you may think. Headlines last week trumpeted the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's finding that the average U.S. life expectancy for a newborn declined by 1.5 years in 2020, and more for blacks and Hispanics. It's fake news, the result of a misinterpreted statistic. In reality, a person born today can almost certainly expect to live as long as or longer than he could have expected a year ago.

title: 'The Man in the Mask' Review: Prisoner of Mystery
summary: Jailers were told to keep him from communicating with anyone-for years. What awful crime had he committed to merit such treatment?. History possesses more than a few mysteries. Josephine Wilkinson took up one of them in "The Princes in the Tower" (2013), a biographical quest in which she tried to determine whether Richard III had indeed had his two young nephews murdered to secure his seizure of the English crown. Now she takes up another: What was the identity of the Man in the Iron Mask, the strangely disguised figure who was kept in prison for decades by order of Louis XIV?

title: American Airlines Pilots and Flight Attendants Unions Say They Can't Find Hotel Rooms
summary: Complaints another sign of air travel's growing pains, as surge in demand this summer overwhelms tourism hot spots, hotels, airports. It isn't only travelers finding more crowds and fuller hotels this summer. Some flight attendants say they are running into the same problem.

title: Fed Says Economy Has Made Progress Toward Its Goals, Teeing Up Bond Taper
summary: Officials will assess whether to begin shrinking their $120 billion in monthly asset purchases in coming meetings. WASHINGTON-The Federal Reserve inched toward scaling back the easy-money policies adopted at the start of the pandemic by signaling that the process could start later this year.

title: Apple to Require Employees, Customers to Wear Masks in Many U.S. Stores
summary: The company has also told workers in corporate offices to wear masks regardless of vaccination status. Apple Inc. plans to require employees and customers to wear masks in more than half its U.S. retail stores regardless of their vaccination status, according to a memo sent to some of its workers Wednesday.

title: Baxter in Early Talks to Buy Medical-Device Maker Hill-Rom
summary: Discussions follow a $144-a-share bid from Baxter that Hill-Rom rebuffed, some people familiar with the matter say. Baxter International Inc. is in talks to buy medical-equipment maker Hill-Rom Holdings Inc., according to people familiar with the matter, the latest potential tie-up in a boom year for healthcare deal making.

title: Pfizer Vaccine's Protection Against Covid-19 Declines After Six Months
summary: New data shows efficacy drops to 84% from a peak of 96% within two months of vaccination. Protection against symptomatic Covid-19 from Pfizer Inc. and partner BioNTech SE's vaccine diminished over time but remained strong after six months, according to data released by the companies Wednesday.

title: 'Real' Government-Bond Yields Tumble to Record Lows
summary: Decline in U.S., European yields adjusted for inflation is a sign that investors are paring bets on rapid economic recovery. Yields on government bonds in the U.S. and Europe have dropped to record lows when adjusted for inflation, a sign of investors' waning optimism about the global economic recovery.

title: Russia at the Tokyo Olympics Is Still Trying to Be Russia
summary: The country's athletes are competing as ROC-and fighting to maintain their identities without the bear symbol or national anthem. TOKYO-For most athletes, getting ready for the Olympics involves training camps, trial competitions and mental preparation. For Russians, it also includes horse-trading over bears and music.

title: Fed Launches Standing Repo Facility to Boost Market Liquidity
summary: The Fed is putting a $500 billion cap on the facility and is offering a similar tool to foreign central banks. The Federal Reserve is launching new facilities designed to provide liquidity to big Wall Street banks and foreign institutions like central banks, which could help ensure market stability at times of stress.

title: Are Employee Covid-19 Vaccine Mandates Legal? What to Know
summary: Employers generally can require shots, but accommodations must be made for religious objections, disabled people and unionized workers. Large employers have begun moving to compel their employees to be vaccinated or get tested regularly for Covid-19, with California and New York City taking the first steps.

title: Treasury Yields Edge Higher After Fed Signal
summary: Central bank says U.S. economy has made progress toward its employment and inflation goals. U.S. government bond yields edged higher Wednesday after the Federal Reserve signaled it was getting closer to when it could start tapering bond purchases.

title: Citizens Financial to Buy Investors Bancorp in $3.5 Billion Deal
summary: Latest regional bank tie-up follows Citizens' agreement to buy East Coast branches and online deposit business of HSBC Holding. Citizens Financial Group Inc. on Wednesday said it agreed to buy Investors Bancorp Inc. in a $3.5 billion cash-and-stock deal that will expand Citizens' presence in several lucrative East Coast markets.

title: Police Officer Who Shot Jay Anderson in Milwaukee Suburb in 2016 to Be Prosecuted
summary: Court will appoint special prosecutor to lead case against officer who was involved in three fatal shootings over five years. A Wisconsin judge has ruled that police officer Joseph Mensah can be prosecuted for the 2016 killing of Jay Anderson, a Black man whose fatal shooting sparked protests last year.

title: Qualcomm Sees Path Out of Chip Shortage Stretching Into 2022
summary: Mobile-phone chip giant sees stronger-than-expected demand for 5G smartphones. Qualcomm Inc. says its get-them-where-you-can approach to navigating the global semiconductor shortage is working, though the mobile-phone chip giant sees the supply crunch lasting into next year.

title: Sandy Hook Families Offered $33 Million Settlement by Gun Maker Remington
summary: Two of the bankrupt firearms manufacturer's insurers are backing the offer of $3.66 million each for nine families, a person with knowledge of the case said. Remington Arms Co. has offered to pay nearly $33 million to settle claims that its marketing practices were in part responsible for the Sandy Hook school massacre that left 20 first-graders and six faculty dead, according to court documents.

title: Gunman in Pakistan Fires on Car Carrying Chinese Engineers
summary: The attack was the latest on China's citizens in the country, which is a close ally of Beijing. ISLAMABAD, Pakistan-A gunman opened fire on a car carrying two engineers in the southern port city of Karachi, the latest attack on Chinese nationals in close ally Pakistan.

title: Dow Closes Lower After Fed Statement
summary: Stocks still hover near all-time highs, with major indexes having closed at records on Monday. Stocks held steady Wednesday after the Federal Reserve hinted that it was getting closer to curtailing a key asset-purchasing program that has helped juice the U.S. economic recovery.

title: U.S., India Pledge Commitment to Afghanistan Amid Taliban Gains
summary: Secretary of State Antony Blinken's visit was in part aimed at reassuring Indian leaders as American troops withdraw. NEW DELHI-Top diplomats from the U.S. and India said the two countries were committed to resolving the conflict in Afghanistan, while acknowledging the Taliban have made new territorial gains, sparking fears in New Delhi about an increase in terrorism.

title: FTC Head Blames Digital Platforms for Surge in Consumer Fraud
summary: Testimony by Federal Trade Commission chairwoman indicates big technology companies will be target. WASHINGTON-Federal Trade Commission Chairwoman Lina Khan took aim at big technology companies in her first appearance before Congress as the agency's head, saying online digital platforms are partly to blame for a surge in fraud reported by Americans during the pandemic.

title: Ye Olde Producte Placement (Thursday Crossword, July 29)
Why Outdoor Entertaining Is More Trouble Than It's Worth
summary: Décor columnist Michelle Slatalla won't be talked out of her distaste for dining outside, a wildly popular activity she finds overrated. WHEN I LIVED on Long Island, every May 15 I resolved to entertain outdoors throughout the entire summer. The weather was just perfect! We put a jaunty green canvas canopy over our back patio, got out the wicker furniture and made a long list of outdoor weekend dinner parties we'd host up until and including Labor Day.

title: January 6 and the 'Insurrection' Thesis
summary: Sentences handed out so far are for lesser offenses.. Since the disgraceful events of January 6, there's been a partisan debate over whether the Capitol riot was an attempted coup or a political protest gone horribly wrong. So far, sentences handed out to participants suggest the latter.

title: Biden Proposes Buy American Rule for Federal Procurements
summary: Under the rule, contractors would be required to prove American content. WASHINGTON-The Biden administration proposed a rule that would accelerate federal procurement policy to require a higher level of American-made products.

title: U.K. to Open Up to Vaccinated American Travelers
summary: U.S. visitors to be able to enter without quarantine as government hopes for influx of tourists and bankers. LONDON-The U.K. is open to American visitors again.

title: Fro-Jito
summary: This frozen riff on the classic Mojito uses Rumple Minze liqueur instead of fresh mint for a clean, frosty version without little flecks of green herb in the mix. To explore and search through all our recipes, check out the new WSJ Recipes page.

title: Justice Department Warns States Over New Voting Laws
summary: Biden administration signals intention to enforce federal election laws as some Republican-led states pass measures narrowing voting options. WASHINGTON-The Justice Department warned states on Wednesday that they must comply with federal election laws, underscoring the Biden administration's focus on voting access as some Republican-led states have passed new laws narrowing voting options that were expanded during the pandemic.

title: Boat Drinks Bring the Summer Vibe-Even if You're Landlocked
summary: These easy-to-make, easy-to-drink cocktails conjure a cruise around Key West. Start with this recipe for an icy, refreshing Fro-Jito.. IN 1979 the singer-songwriter and patron saint of island escapism, Jimmy Buffett, released a song called "Boat Drinks." While it captures the deep-winter yearning to "go where there ain't any snow," the lyrics go into zero detail about just what goes into a boat drink.

title: Biden Plans to Require Covid Vaccine or Regular Tests for Federal Workers
summary: The move, which could affect millions of workers, would represent the latest effort to address Delta variant. President Biden is expected to announce Thursday that his administration will require federal employees to get vaccinated or be regularly tested for Covid-19, according to a person familiar with the discussions.

title: Boeing Swings to Profit on Defense and Jet Sales
summary: Aircraft orders and defense business underpin improvement, as 10,000 job cuts are shelved amid the airline industry's recovery. Boeing Co. reported its first quarterly profit in nearly two years and said it needs orders from China to participate fully in a stronger-than-expected recovery in air travel.

title: Covid-19 Fueled a Treasury Market Meltdown in 2020. Report Offers Potential Fixes.
summary: Regulators face questions over how to avoid more frequent dysfunction. A global dash for cash sparked by the coronavirus pandemic in March 2020 forced the Federal Reserve to buy hundreds of billions of dollars of U.S. Treasury securities in a matter of days to prevent a broader meltdown in financial markets.

title: Battery Recycler Redwood Eyes Expansion Amid Shift to Electric Vehicles
summary: Redwood Materials raised more than $700 million in new funding as investors increase bets on battery-materials companies. Battery-recycling company Redwood Materials Inc. has raised more than $700 million in new funding as demand grows for materials used in the batteries that power electric vehicles.

title: What Good Is Common-Good Constitutionalism?
summary: It isn't so different from the 'living constitution' movement of a half-century ago.. Regarding David Rivkin and Andrew Grossman's "The Temptation of the 'Common Good'" (op-ed, July 24): There is always a temptation to seek a shortcut around the hard work of politics and persuading our fellow citizens to embrace the principles and practices that we think are right. Theories of judicially enforced "living constitutionalism" have long sought precisely such a shortcut. Jurists like William Brennan argued that judges should impose the rule that they think best and hope that the people would eventually come around to accepting the rule, and the imposition, as just.

title: Some Republicans Reject Revived Covid-19 Mask Rules in Congress
summary: GOP's Kevin McCarthy and Democrat Nancy Pelosi trade gibes over Capitol physician office's reversal in face of Delta variant's spread. WASHINGTON-Several House Republicans flouted rules reimposing mask requirements on the House floor to stop the spread of Covid-19, with some GOP lawmakers angrily denouncing the new effort while congressional leaders traded insults.

title: Barclays Profit Soars on Investment Banking
summary: Chief Executive Jes Staley has staked his strategy on reinvigorating the investment bank. LONDON- Barclays PLC Wednesday said its net profit rose in the second quarter, driven by a strong performance in its investment bank.

title: Tax-Friendly Philanthropy Needs Guardrails
summary: It isn't a woke attack to ensure that charitable tax rules get resources to charities and the beneficiaries they serve.. Naomi Schaefer Riley's "The Weekend Interview with Elise Westhoff: The Woke Threat to Philanthropy" (July 17) illustrates a misunderstanding of the tax rules governing philanthropy and of the proposals of the Initiative to Accelerate Charitable Giving, embodied in the ACE Act. Rather than being part of a "woke takeover of philanthropy," this bipartisan bill, introduced by a Republican (Iowa Sen. Chuck Grassley) and an independent (Maine Sen. Angus King), adopts important guardrails to ensure that charitable tax rules fulfill their intended purpose-getting resources to charities and the beneficiaries they serve.

title: The Difference Between a Comedian and a Comic
summary: Jerry Lewis said things funny. He was a comic.. In "The Martin and Lewis Decade" (op-ed, July 26), Tevi Troy characterizes Jerry Lewis as "a rubber-faced, hyperkinetic Jewish comedian who seemed as if he couldn't stand still for a moment." But an old adage teaches that comedians are different from comics: Comedians say funny things, while comics say things funny. Lewis was definitely among the latter.

title: Be Proud That U.S. Olympic Athletes Are Free to Protest
summary: America's innate rebelliousness against things like 'appropriate patriotic decorum' is our superpower.. In "Unpatriotic Athletes Should Not Represent This Country" (Letters, July 26), one of your readers urges the banishment from Olympic teams of those athletes who fail to behave with "appropriate patriotic decorum." That sounds a lot like something China would do to pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong. I think we should be proud to live in a country that allows people to protest (however misguided or not they may be)-and also win gold medals. America's innate rebelliousness against things like "appropriate patriotic decorum" is our superpower, and we shouldn't forget it.

title: Pfizer Forecasts $33.5 Billion in Covid-19 Vaccine Sales
summary: Company raises full-year outlook as it prepares to ask U.S. regulators to authorize booster shots. Pfizer Inc. expects sales for its Covid-19 vaccine this year to reach about $33.5 billion, up nearly 30% from its forecast three months ago, as the shot plays a growing role in global efforts to curb the spread of the coronavirus.

title: The Pandemic Isn't Over Yet
summary: Vaccination remains urgent.. As a retired physician and Covid survivor, I was saddened and disturbed by your article "Young Adults Pass on Vaccines," (U.S. News, July 12), especially the comments of the Texas A&M student you quote. His facts are wrong. Covid cases are increasing, not decreasing, and from what I read, public-health officials are very concerned about a new spike occurring in the fall.

title: Robinhood Is Warning You About Certain Risks Before You Invest in Its IPO
summary: The trading app has grown explosively-and at times painfully-and challenges lie ahead as it makes its anticipated debut. Robinhood Markets Inc. is urging its users to invest in its eagerly awaited initial public offering, setting aside as much as 35% of the shares being sold for individuals to buy. And like other companies going public, the trading-app company laid out in its prospectus certain risk factors associated with its business that it thinks investors should be aware of before buying in.

title: Tiny Bhutan Stages Quick Covid-19 Vaccination Effort
summary: While bigger South Asian neighbors such as India and Bangladesh fall way behind in their vaccination efforts, Bhutan inoculates 90% of eligible adults. The Himalayan nation of Bhutan completed a rapid-fire Covid-19 vaccination campaign, fully inoculating 90% of its eligible adult population, a bright spot in the region that is still badly lagging behind rich countries in administering the shot.

title: SEC Weighs Making Companies Liable for Climate Disclosures
summary: Chairman asks staff to consider whether climate-related statements should be required in 10-K annual reports. WASHINGTON-Public companies could be required to disclose climate-change related risks to investors in regulatory filings under a proposal being formulated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, a step that could expose them to new litigation threats.

title: The Latest Pandemic Travel Trend: Adults-Only Luxury Resort Vacations
summary: After too much together time during lockdown, parents are ditching the kids. These six luxury resorts all cater to grown-ups and offer serene, sophisticated diversions, from wine-tasting in Napa to catnaps on Italy's Amalfi Coast.. THE PANDEMIC BROUGHT many families closer together, but even the tightest clans can squabble over Scrabble matches after one too many game nights. A surfeit of together-time is triggering a rise in demand for kid-free vacations, said Jack Ezon, founder of travel company Embark Beyond. Sixty-one percent of the summer trips that Embark Beyond booked this year were for adults only, compared with 48% in 2019. These grown-up escapes aren't just for couples. Some are booked by groups of friends who want to travel together after many months of Zoom-only contact or individuals seeking solo sojourns. To help you plan your own immersion in maturity we've selected five resorts that offer decidedly grown-up diversions, from wining and dining to flopping down on a beach with a thick page-turner and uninterrupted nap time.

title: New York or Oregon? Thanks to Bicoastal Living, This Couple Didn't Have to Choose
summary: Resume Subscription. Rob Willey, a startup executive, and his wife, Remy Allis, a branding entrepreneur, wanted out of New York City when the pandemic began. The couple, who grew up in Oregon and Idaho, respectively, found themselves longing to be closer to family and somewhere their 7-year-old son, Ford , could explore the outdoors.

title: SBA to Simplify PPP Loan Forgiveness for Smallest Borrowers
summary: Agency will allow borrowers of $150,000 or less to apply directly for forgiveness, if their banks join program. The Small Business Administration said it would make it easier for the smallest businesses that got funds from the Paycheck Protection Program to have their loans forgiven, as the agency seeks to wind down the Covid-19 rescue program.

title: Indianapolis Gunman Didn't Commit Hate Crime, Investigators Find
summary: The 19-year old shooter, who killed eight people at a FedEx facility in April, was trying to prove his masculinity before dying by suicide, according to investigators. The gunman who killed eight people at a FedEx Corp. facility in Indianapolis in April was likely not motivated by bias or racism, investigators said Wednesday.

title: China Meets With Taliban, Stepping Up as U.S. Exits Afghanistan
summary: Foreign minister, signaling a growing role for Beijing in the country, urges group to pursue peace efforts. China's foreign minister urged the Taliban to distance itself from terrorist groups and take steps to establish peace in Afghanistan, in a meeting with the group on Chinese soil that signaled Beijing is stepping in diplomatically as the U.S. withdraws from the country.

title: Japan Has a New Gymnastics Prince
summary: Resume Subscription. TOKYO-Japan has crowned new gymnastics royalty, as Daiki Hashimoto secured a coveted gold all-around medal to succeed the beloved two-time Olympic champion Kohei Uchimura.

title: Retailers Lean on Software to Combat Rising Costs
summary: AI systems trained on large amounts of sales data are helping grocery stores and other retailers price items. Supermarkets, sports stores and other retailers are putting software to work in efforts to lessen the impact of rising prices, with a growing number of stores adopting artificial-intelligence tools designed to manage price increases in a way that won't chase shoppers away.

title: Covid-19 Keeps Resurging, but Western Economies Are Adapting
summary: Vaccinations have been decisive factor in limiting Delta variant's impact; governments and businesses also have adjusted policies. Western economies are learning to live with Covid-19. As each successive wave of the coronavirus has washed over the West, the virus has wreaked less economic damage than the last time around.

title: Google's Costs Have Catching Up to Do
summary: Surge in operating profit comes as R&D, capex and sales expenditures track below normal. Google's great quarter may have been a little too great.

title: Apple and Tesla Are the Chip Shortage's Latest Victims
summary: The supply-chain woes for microprocessors are hitting those once seen less affected. The chip shortage is about to hit the iPhone.

title: Why Is the FDA Attacking a Safe, Effective Drug?
summary: Ivermectin is a promising Covid treatment and prophylaxis, but the agency is denigrating it.. The Food and Drug Administration claims to follow the science. So why is it attacking ivermectin, a medication it certified in 1996?

title: A Democrat Against Deficits
summary: Congress should pay for its infrastructure spending, not look for creative ways of avoiding responsibility.. America needs more infrastructure. We don't need billions of dollars more debt added to the mountain of debt we already owe. Unfortunately, some congressional Republicans and Democrats who agree on little else are prepared to do exactly that-add billions in red ink rather than fully pay for their infrastructure plans. The real test will come when the Congressional Budget Office releases its official cost estimates of the bills concluding whether the savings are sufficient to cover their expense fully.

title: U.S. Sanctions Syrians Linked to Alleged Atrocities
summary: Action is a public censure of the Assad regime and its supporters including Russia and Iran, analysts say, given the targeted officials' limited exposure. WASHINGTON-The U.S. Treasury Department levied sanctions against five senior Syrian security officials and eight prisons accused of committing human-rights abuses, the start of what the Biden administration says will be its campaign to hold the Assad regime accountable for war crimes.

title: Pfizer Stock Doesn't Need a Booster Shot
summary: Covid-19 vaccine sales are still brisk, but the rest of Pfizer's business is in fine health. Pfizer 's Covid-19 vaccine bonanza isn't showing signs of slowing down just yet. but second-quarter results out Wednesday suggest shareholders are inoculated for that eventuality.

title: Biden Directs Agencies to Develop Cybersecurity Standards for Critical Infrastructure
summary: Though voluntary, officials said the new step could be a prelude to a push for cybersecurity mandates. WASHINGTON-President Biden on Wednesday issued a new directive instructing federal agencies to develop voluntary cybersecurity goals for companies that operate U.S. critical infrastructure, a move that came as senior officials said the administration was exploring the possibility of pursuing mandatory standards.

title: Boeing Is Mostly Over the Pandemic, but Not Its Own Problems
summary: Issues still threaten plane maker's competitive position. Boeing is making money again, but regaining its status as an investor darling will take something more.

title: McDonald's Sales Surpass Pre-Pandemic Levels
summary: Burger giant says hiring, equipment supply are challenges; fewer Covid-19 restrictions aid business. McDonald's Corp. said its sales are surpassing pre-pandemic levels across the world as more of its dining rooms reopen and U.S. customers try new chicken offerings.

title: Washington's Oil Lobby Pivoted on Climate Change-and Made No One Happy
summary: The American Petroleum Institute's green makeover has been met with skepticism from friends and foes alike. WASHINGTON-The American Petroleum Institute, Washington's biggest lobby for the oil-and-gas industry, spent decades leveraging its financial muscle to fight almost every green initiative in its path.

title: How to Build a Career Path in 3 Steps
summary: Most Popular News. Whether you are looking for a job for the first time or seeking to make a move in the middle of your career, having a plan is the surest way to find fulfillment and happiness in your professional life. It is better to forge a career path than let yourself get too comfortable and complacent where you are, according to career coach Tracy Timm and recruitment trends expert Tony Lee. That can be a "recipe for disaster," says Miss Timm.

title: Europe's Lenders Want to Grow Their Investment Banks Again
summary: Keeping busy in capital markets has helped Barclays and Deutsche Bank deliver steady performances but plans to expand their investment banks still seem risky.. Barclays and Deutsche Bank are on form right now, but investors need to be cautious of their growing ambitions for the volatile investment-banking business.

title: Spotify Adds Fewer Total Users Than Expected
summary: Streaming audio service says ad revenue more than doubles, helped by podcasts from Joe Rogan and Bill Simmons. Spotify Technology SA's advertising revenue more than doubled in the most recent quarter, helped by growth in its podcast business, but the company added fewer total users than expected.

title: Rollins Names Interim Finance Chief Amid SEC Probe
summary: Julie Bimmerman, who has been vice president of finance and investor relations since 2018, will serve as interim chief financial officer and treasurer. Rollins Inc. Wednesday said it has named an interim finance chief amid a continuing investigation by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission into the pest-control company's accounting practices.

title: U.S. Women Win First Ever 3-on-3 Basketball Olympic Gold
summary: Resume Subscription. TOKYO-The first gold medal ever won in Olympic 3-on-3 basketball had the distinct flavor of a game played on schoolyards and street corners. Elbows flew wildly. Players checked their mouths for blood. The players didn't seem to like one another.

title: We Live in a Golden Age of Dinosaur Chicken Nuggets
summary: The 'fun nugget' boomlet taught makers to use fewer spikes, leave room for breading; now, perfecting Baby Yoda's ears. If Mark Tolbert could redesign his company's Tyrannosaurus rex chicken nugget, he would make the neck slightly slimmer and the head a bit bigger.

title: Is 'Stillwater' This Summer's Grown-Up Crowd Pleaser?
summary: Cheered at Cannes, the new Matt Damon movie is now rolling the dice on a theaters-only release. Covid-19 may have created a disaster for theatrical releases and movie theaters, but it turns out the disruption worked out for Tom McCarthy. The director of "Stillwater," starring Matt Damon as a father trying to get his daughter out of a French prison, says the pandemic delay gave him a chance that studio-backed filmmakers rarely get-to step away from the film for months and come back to sharpen it with fresh eyes.

title: Jackie Mason, When Told He Was Too Jewish, Stuck With His Shtick
summary: Comedian, a former rabbi who has died at age 93, defied taboos and finally hit the big time on Broadway. Jackie Mason's career was an illustration of the value of believing in a product despite others' doubts and finding, through trial and error, an effective way to market it.

title: Grilled Rib-Eye Skewers With Roasted Peppers and a Green Salad
summary: This recipe gets maximum flavor from rib-eye with minimal time and effort. Roasted piquillo peppers and a simple green salad provide bracing complements.. To explore and search through all our recipes, check out the new WSJ Recipes page.

title: Friendship Necklaces and Bracelets: All Grown-Up
summary: The jewelry you once made at summer camp is back in style-with an elevated look and price tag. Same BFF, new necklace.. When brand consultant Natasha Berg, 30, was a child, she constantly gave her friends matching half-heart metal friendship necklaces or handmade beaded and string friendship bracelets to show the world that she had the best BFFs ever. Recently, when a friend from high school was paralyzed, Berg wanted to send a gift to her that she knew would have special meaning. She purchased matching custom-made friendship bracelets ($28 at fybjewelry.com) in one of her friend's favorite colors of sodalite stones with an 18K gold charm.

title: How to Grill Steak This Summer: Simply, Skewered
summary: This recipe gets maximum flavor from rib-eye with minimal time and effort. Roasted piquillo peppers and a simple green salad provide bracing complements.. A GOOD STEAK requires no sauce, in chef Ryan Bartlow's opinion. At Ernesto's in Manhattan, he often serves excellent cuts sauceless and free of fussy sides so diners can better appreciate the meat itself.

title: They Got Great Deals on Airfare. Then Came the Flight Changes.
summary: Fliers who thought they'd scored cheap fares on Delta and other airlines are getting rebooked on longer, less convenient itineraries-and that's just the start of their headaches. What's one difference between airline tickets and lottery tickets? With lottery tickets you know when the event will occur.

title: Eddy Alvarez Seeks to Complete a Matching Set of Summer and Winter Medals
summary: He skated to a silver medal at the 2014 Sochi Games. Now he's hunting for the Summer Olympics version in baseball.. Of the nearly 8 billion people currently on this planet, only three can truly comprehend the difficulty of what Eddy Alvarez is attempting to accomplish. That's the number of living athletes who possessed the skill, passion and drive to win medals at the Summer and Winter Olympics.

title: Apple, Facebook, Mattel, Teladoc Health: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Futures are wobbling after Wall Street broke a five-session winning streak. S&P 500 heavyweights Apple, Microsoft and Alphabet reported huge profits after the bell last night-though the tech giants themselves are turning in a mixed performance premarket, and stock futures are wobbling near the flat line.

title: 'I Need to Call It': Behind Simone Biles's Stunning Olympic Withdrawal
summary: Eight years ago, Simone Biles had to be forced off the competition floor by her then-coach over her mental state. In 2021, the greatest gymnast of all time insisted to team staff that she was removing herself.. TOKYO-Simone Biles was in the wrong head space to compete. She had already fallen. She had hurt her ankle. She tried to push on, but it became clear she was endangering herself by doing so. A choice was made: Biles would be withdrawn from the competition.

title: China Prepares New Anti-Sanction Laws for Hong Kong and Macau
summary: Rules threaten to punish companies that comply with U.S. and European bans. China's government is planning to introduce new laws in Hong Kong and Macau that could bar foreign entities and individuals in the cities from complying with sanctions against China, according to people familiar with the discussions.

title: Wharton Is First Elite M.B.A. Program to Enroll More Women Than Men
summary: Dean of the University of Pennsylvania's business school says Covid-19 'wreaked havoc' on women's careers. The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania will mark a milestone this fall: A majority of incoming M.B.A. candidates will be women.

title: How to Wear a Suit in 2021? Over a T-Shirt, Apparently
summary: To ease the transition from lockdown sweats to more-tailored fare, some men are wearing casual T-shirts-not stuffy button-downs-under their sport coats. BEN HELMS DIDN'T want to wear a dress shirt. Last month, the 28-year-old, who works in tech sales in Chicago, was attending his first wedding since the onset of Covid. He picked out a handsome golden-brown suit from Bonobos for the occasion, but instead of starting with a formal button-up, Mr. Helms slipped a Uniqlo T-shirt underneath the suit. The unconventional wedding outfit garnered some ribbing from other guests-more than a few called him "Miami Vice"-but Mr. Helms has no regrets about opting for dressed-down ease. "I felt like the T-shirt under gave that sense of 'I'm put together, but it's not overly formal,'" he said.

title: Katie Ledecky Wins First Gold in Tokyo, Even as Rivals Catch Up
summary: Resume Subscription. TOKYO-Katie Ledecky won her first gold medal of the Tokyo Games in the Olympic debut of her signature event, the 1,500-meter freestyle, on Wednesday. In victory, however, it was also clear how much the rest of the world has caught up to her.

title: New Food-Delivery Battlefield Has Wurst Appeal
summary: Uber Eats and DoorDash may be able to best Just Eat Takeaway.com in Germany, but doing so will cost them. Both Uber Technologies ' Uber Eats and DoorDash appear to have their sights set on the German market-a unique one controlled by a single player amid a global land grab in food delivery. An activist presentation this week shows Germany's allure isn't necessarily its diners but the ability to weaken a vulnerable incumbent.

title: Robinhood Walks IPO Pricing Tightrope
summary: It will be difficult for Robinhood to both deliver huge gains to its customers and also show itself to be a major future IPO player. Initial public offerings can be a little bit like politics: A decent outcome may be when everyone is only a little bit unhappy. The question is whether even that will be achievable for Robinhood Markets.

title: Rio Tinto First-Half Profit Sets Record on Commodity Price Surge
summary: Mining titan benefits from elevated prices, which have stirred debate about whether markets are entering an extended boom. SYDNEY- Rio Tinto PLC reported a record first-half net profit and more than tripled its midyear payout to shareholders, benefiting from a bull run in commodity prices that has stoked inflation expectations around the world.

title: As China Cleans Up Flooded City, Authorities Keep a Grip on Information
summary: Police stop people from taking photos of hard-hit areas, tell reporters they can't cover flood response without official clearance. ZHENGZHOU, China-Days after the heaviest flooding in memory hit Zhengzhou, the cleanup was beginning amid an increasingly tight security presence that was already constricting the flow of information.

title: Fencers Refused to Fight. Then Came the Rule That Changed the Sport.
summary: Resume Subscription. CHIBA, Japan-Fencing had a problem. The world's best fencers were refusing to actually fence.

title: Russian Gymnast Nikita Nagornyy Is Armed With a New Move to Help Him Win Gold
summary: Resume Subscription. TOKYO-Nikita Nagornyy, a 24-year old Russian who has emerged as the new ruler of men's gymnastics in recent years, had a secret: a never-before performed element known as the triple back pike.

title: What Simone Biles Was Saying
summary: An iconic Olympian hits pause on the planet's biggest athletic stage, widening the conversation about mental health in sports. Tokyo

title: After Navalny, Challenging Putin Is Getting Even Harder
summary: Opposition leaders have been detained, media sidelined and legal rights groups forced to disband in run-up to parliamentary elections in September. MOSCOW-Challenging Vladimir Putin has always been difficult. Now his opponents say it is almost impossible, as the Kremlin launches a full-court press against anyone daring to stand up against the Russian president.

title: Fed Meeting Will Focus on Tapering Timeline
summary: Officials are looking to forge consensus on how and when to eventually reduce their asset purchases.

title: GOP Bill Attempts to Inject Life Into Stalled Internet Privacy Talks
summary: Senate proposal reverts to a 2019 draft bill that faced Democratic opposition. With work toward a federal privacy law largely stalled for the past 18 months, a top GOP lawmaker is trying to turn back the clock.

title: HBCUs Use Pandemic Funds to Forgive Student Debt
summary: By clearing past-due balances, historically Black colleges and universities pave the way for students to re-enroll or get their diplomas. Almost all 2,000 students at South Carolina State University owed money to the school by the end of spring semester this year. Some owed less than a dollar, others were hundreds or even thousands of dollars past due on expenses such as tuition payments and housing fees.

title: Hot Housing Market Lets Banks Sell Mortgage Risk
summary: Banks are now bundling and selling default risk on mortgage loans to yield-hungry investors. A red-hot housing market is enabling banks to sell a new kind of bond that shares the risk of mortgage and loan defaults with institutional investors.

title: 'The Boy Behind the Door' Review: Stranger Danger
summary: In Justin Powell and David Charbonier's horror flick on Shudder, two tween boys are kidnapped and taken to a remote location, where one risks his life in a race to help the other escape.. Horror is the jazz of movie genres. The music relies, often enough, on standards (Cole Porter, George Gershwin, Richard Rodgers, Stephen Sondheim). The films, almost invariably, rely on a selection of standard devices-the old dark house, the cabin on the lake, the homicidal maniac with mother issues and designated victims who say, "I'll be right back." What makes one performance or film better than another are the variations. The interpretations. The spins and tweaks. And creaks. You see it a lot on the AMC-owned service Shudder. You see it throughout "The Boy Behind the Door."

title: 'The Immortal' Review: Mob Family Reunion
summary: An offshoot of the TV series 'Gomorrah,' this HBO Max feature film directed by and starring Marco D'Amore follows the life and near death of Ciro, a member of an Italian crime organization. Making the point of its title, "The Immortal" begins with its hero being shot to death-or so viewers will be led to think, as they watch mobster Ciro Di Marzio (Marco D'Amore) descend into the Bay of Naples. Anyone familiar with Ciro, aka "L'Immortale," will suspect that something else is happening. Especially after his "corpse" resurfaces in Latvia, haunted by Neapolitans both alive and dead.

title: Deutsche Bank Posts Surge in Profit but Faces Headwinds
summary: Frankfurt-based lender reports drop in revenue as client activity slowed after booming during the pandemic. Deutsche Bank AG's results signaled that the bumper profits accruing to its investment bank may have peaked, exposing the deeper challenges the lender faces two years into a strategic makeover.

title: Simone Biles Withdraws From Olympic All-Around Final
summary: The decision comes after the star U.S. gymnast pulled herself out of the team competition. TOKYO-U.S. gymnastics star Simone Biles said she is withdrawing from Thursday's individual all-around final at the Tokyo Olympics, a decision that comes a day after she pulled herself out of the team competition saying she wasn't in the right mental place to continue.

title: Jake Ellzey Wins Texas Special Election, Upsetting Trump-Endorsed Candidate
summary: The GOP state representative will represent the congressional district south of Dallas. WASHINGTON-GOP state Rep. Jake Ellzey won a special election runoff in Texas on Tuesday, unexpectedly defeating the widow of the GOP lawmaker he will replace in the U.S. House, according to the Associated Press.

title: J&J Talc Claimants Seek to Pre-Empt Company's Bankruptcy Strategy
summary: Separately, lawmakers probe company over whether it plans to address talc-related injury claims through bankruptcy. People alleging that Johnson & Johnson 's talc-based baby powder caused their cancers asked a federal court to forbid the company from taking steps to place its talc liabilities in bankruptcy, while lawmakers sought information about the same issue from J&J's CEO.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Justice Department Won't Defend GOP Lawmaker in Jan. 6 Riot Suit
summary: Department says congressman's rally speech wasn't an official function. WASHINGTON-The Justice Department said it wouldn't defend Rep. Mo Brooks (R., Ala.) against a lawsuit alleging he helped incite the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol, concluding the congressman wasn't acting in his official capacity when he encouraged pro-Trump demonstrators to "start taking down names and kicking ass" at a rally shortly beforehand.

title: CDC Urges Vaccinated People to Resume Masking Indoors in Some Areas
summary: Move marks a change from agency's earlier guidance as highly contagious Delta variant spreads. WASHINGTON-The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, citing the highly transmissible Delta variant, recommended Tuesday that vaccinated people resume masking indoors in certain parts of the country and that K-12 schools adopt universal masking for teachers, staff, students and visitors regardless of vaccination status.

title: Marjorie Taylor Greene, Other GOP Lawmakers Sue Pelosi Over Mask Penalties
summary: The Georgia Congresswoman, Thomas Massie of Kentucky and Ralph Norman of South Carolina were fined $500 for not wearing masks. WASHINGTON -- Three House Republican lawmakers filed a lawsuit accusing House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D., Calif.) of violating the Constitution when their pay was docked for refusing to wear face coverings on the House floor earlier this year.

title: Starbucks Sales Outpace Pre-Pandemic Levels
summary: Coffee giant's U.S. business rebounds to help quarterly sales outpace pre-pandemic levels; profit outlook rises. Starbucks Corp. said higher labor and supply costs are likely to linger for months, adding that it is promoting higher-end beverages such as cold coffee and could lift prices in areas to help compensate.

title: Ride-Sharing Startup Swvl Nearing Deal to Go Public With Female-Led SPAC
summary: Middle East-based ride-sharing and technology company plans to merge with Queen's Gambit Growth Capital. Middle East-based ride-sharing technology startup Swvl Inc. is nearing a deal to go public via a merger with a special-purpose acquisition company, according to people familiar with the matter.
